h1_title: Automatically check APA citations in PDFs and detect AI-generated false references
intro_text: Accurate citations are essential to any scholarly work. Citalyze automatically reviews your PDF: in-text citations are matched to the reference list, and each source is verified through the CrossRef database. This makes it easy to identify missing or incorrect references, as well as fabricated sources often found in AI-generated content. Increase the reliability of your work, save valuable time, and meet formatting standards with confidence – whether for a term paper, dissertation, or journal article.

faq_q1: 1. What is this software, and what does it do?
faq_a1: This software checks citation accuracy in PDFs, ensuring in-text citations match the reference list. It verifies each reference through CrossRef and lets users search Google Scholar for accuracy.
faq_q3: 3. How do I use the software?
faq_a3: Upload your PDF, and the software will guide you through citation settings. After the analysis is complete, you’ll see an overview of any mismatched in-text citations and references in your document.
faq_a4: The software detects citations and references following the APA style. The results for other reference styles are currently not reliable. Matching may work for other reference styles similar to APA.
faq_q5: 5. What is the level of accuracy, and what happens if there’s a mismatch?
faq_a5: While we strive for high accuracy, we cannot guarantee 100% precision, as there is always a chance of mismatches due to limitations in analyzing PDF text and detecting citations and references. If the software detects a mismatch, it will highlight the discrepancy, allowing the user to manually verify and match in-text citations and references.
faq_q2: 2. Can Citalyze detect AI-generated false references?
faq_a2: Yes. Many AI text generators invent references or mix real with false sources. Citalyze compares each reference against the CrossRef database and flags those that do not exist or contain incorrect details.

tooltip_reference_list:
Reference List Overview
Here, users can view all detected references from the reference list. An entry may look like this:
  • Linked in-text citations are shown if a match is found. These citations are clickable and direct you to their location in the document.
  • References with a red border indicate that no in-text citation match was found.
  • Each reference includes a 'best match' section from the Crossref database to help verify the accuracy of the entry in the reference list.
  • A click on will open a Google Scholar search with the detected reference.

tooltip_intext_issues:
In-Text Citation Issues
Here you find all identified in-text citations that show problems when matched against the reference list. Problems can be:
  • Author Year In-text citations without a matching reference in the reference list. You can manually match these by dragging and dropping the citation onto the corresponding entry in the reference list below.
  • Author Year In-text citations with a matching reference, but containing typos or incorrect publication years. You can manually match these by dragging and dropping the citation onto the corresponding entry in the reference list below.
  • Author Year In-text citations matched through abbreviations.
